description.narrative: CREA, is an international feminist women´s human rights organisation based in New Delhi. CREA builds feministic leadership and movements, works for women´s human rights and to expand sexual and reproductive freedom.

Creating Resources for Empowerment and Action Inc, CREA är en internationell feministisk kvinnorättsorganisation baserad i New Delhi, Indien. CREA har inkommit med en förfrågan om stöd på 20 miljoner kronor för en period på fyra år (2016-2019). Detta för att stödja deras Strategiska plan 2015-2020. Ett kärnstöd till CREAs aktiviteter möjliggör för organisationen att uppnå dess strategiska prioriteter och mål.
CREAs strategi syftar till att bygga feministiskt ledarskap och rörelser, arbeta för kvinnors mänskliga rättigheter och för att expandera sexuell och reproduktiv frihet. CREAs arbete följer i huvudsak tre strategier: 1) bygga ledarskapskapacitet, kunskap och färdigheter för i huvudsak aktivister från små, rättighetsbaserade organisationer i syd genom att tillhandahålla kapacitetsbyggande kurser, studieresor och utbytesprogram. 2) Stärka feministiskt ledarskap och rörelser genom att bygga kapacitet för kvinnor att ställa upp i val, att utöva sin rösträtt och engageras sig i beslutsprocesser samt stärka deras ledarskap och möjlighet att mobilisera samhället runt frågor som påverkar kvinnor och flickor. 3) Utöka kunskap och skapa en resursbas från ett sydperspektiv, och utöva påverkan för förändring av lagar, policyer genom nätverkande och samarbete med andra.
I relation till den globala/tematiska resultatstrategin bedömer Sida att relevansen i att stödja CREA är tydlig. Enheten INTEM/DEMO har identifierat behovet av att öka stöd till jämställdhet och till sydbaserade organisationer som når gräsrotsnivån. CREAs mervärde ligger i det faktum att organisationen är sydbaserad och arbetar utifrån ett sydperspektiv med nära koppling till gräsrotsnivån. Detta mervärde blir särskilt tydligt när det gäller frågor som är politiskt och kulturellt känsliga som jämställdhet, sexuella rättigheter inklusive HBTI personers rättigheter då dessa ibland uppfattas som introducerade och ålagda utifrån västerländska värderingar. CREA har ett tydligt fattigdomsperspektiv och rättighetsperspektivet genomsyrar deras arbete.
CREAs totala budget för strategiperioden 2015-2020 är ca 229,190,000 SEK. För närvarande har CREA ca 108,617,000 SEK i säkrade medel med Sidas stöd inräknat.

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

tag.narrative: 16.b - Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.
16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

title.narrative: Beslut om tilldelning av kontrakt EY ISK CREA

description.narrative: 2019/2020 in numbers - 6 institutes held - 1585 sessions/trainings/training of trainers - 108 campaign/events - 3006 individuals trained - 430 128 individuals reached - 447 organisations reached - 193 knowledge resources produced Strengthen Feminist Leadership In April 2019, CREA held its second global conference called "reconference", held in Nepal. The conference brough together shcolarship and critical thinking intersecting with art, technology and feminism. The conference brough together over 700 activists, artists and allies from 63 countries to rethink how to shift power, how ensure that all voices count and how to understand critical issues like consent. CREA reports that the conference redefined traditional notion of "safe spaces" by creating a space for activists and artists to exchange experiences and information and build solidarity. Scholars, activists and policy makers got to explore the divisive issues that drive debates on laws, language and politics across contexts. The event also strengthened CREA's networks, alliances, its movements and collective agendas. Moreover it created a single space for powerful, self-led movements - disability rights, LGBTI rights, youth advocacy and women's rights to continue challenge stigma, violence and discrimination. The South Asia Young Women's Leadership and Mentorship Program SAYWLM. The initiative was launched in 2017, in partnership with the Global Fund for Women, with a model of feminist mentoring to support a new generation of feminist leaders who are transforming their organisations and communities. CREA reports that through the initiative, CREA has build vital knowledge about feminist mentoring that supports young women to become transformative feminist leaders. In 2019, following a training using CREA's feminist leadership institute approach, the young women leaders (YWLs) identified a specific gender-based injustice in the communities in which they work and launched a grassroots movement-building process to tackle it. They also mentored and built the leadership capacity of another 10 women in the community. An example of a result from the training of trainers ToT program is that CREA organised a three-day cross-movement in Uganda. The ToT focused at strengthening and nurturing movements that are conscious of the intersections of gender, sexuality, disability and rights within and among the core constituencies. The training also built collective action around strategies to adress national laws and social norms in Africa that continue to perpetuate GBV and discriminatory gender policies. Advance Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights CREA's work contributed to increased information and knowledge of women, girls, trans, intersex and gender non-binary people, and practitioners on issues related to sexuality, gender, rights and SRHR, including safe abortion. CREA also reports that it contributed to deepened understanding of gender, sexuality and rights and how they intersect among activists, practitioners and organisations in the global South. Moreover, reports that its work contributed to effective advocacy at national, regional and global levels on issues related to sexuality, gender and human rights. Other examples of results are the weeklong campaign #AbortTheStigma, through which CREA challenged audiences to reimagine feminist engagement on abortion to reimagine engagement on abortion through a more critical analysis of the limitations in the way universal human rights standards are applied. For the first time, the campaign created content for a global audience, reaching 60 000 people around the world. CREA is a member of the Sexual Rights Initiative (SRI), a coalition of national and regional organisations. SRI aims to advance sexual rights as a particular set of rights and as a cross-cutting issue within international law, specifically in the work of the Human Rights Council, the UPR, the special procedures and the treaty monitoring bodies. In 2019, CREA and SRI partners were active during the 41st and 42nd sessions of the Human Rights Council and SRI gave input, including oral statements on a total of 13 resolutions. CREA worked with the other members of SRI to introduce human rights language into the resolutions. Address Gender Based Violence and Well-Being CREA reports that its work within this area contributes to increased leadership, awareness and capacity of women and emerging youg girl leaders at all levels, especially at the grassroots level, to combat violence, change harmful social norms and advocate for their rights in an inclusive manner. CREA also reports that its work contributes to increased networking and sharing of knowledge and experiences among activists, organisations and social movements working on issues of peace and security, violence against women and political participation of women with each other. It also contributes to South- South Alliance for raising awareness and strengthening advocacy for all women's human rights, especially reducing violence against all women. In 2019, CREA teamed up with the International Women's Health Coalition and Outright Action International to organise a panel on criminalisation and bodily autonomy at the Women Deliver Conference. During 16 Days of Activism, CREA integrated the digital #FlawsInLaws directly to disability rights organisations and LBQ collectives in Kenya and Uganda, and young women and girls in other community stakeholders within communities in rural, semi-urban and urban areas of India. Increase Voice and Visibility of Marginalized People The inclusion of marginalised women and girls in advocacy efforts to change laws, policies, norms and practices is fundamental to achievening gender equality and human rights, and cuts across all of CREA's strategies. Using a broad range of strategies, including advocacy, knowledge and resource development, training and capacity building, and public events and campaigns, ILGA contributes to increased capacity of disability, LGBTI, women's and sexual rights groups to undertake advocacy at global, regional and national level to address the rights of these constituencies. CREA also reports that it contributes to greater collaboration among persons in prostitution, LGBTI, disabled people, disability rights, women's and sexual rights organisations, and activitst and individuals. As well as increased visibility of the rights of the identified marginalised groups, so that discourses in the field of SRHR become more attentive and inclusive to these issues. In March 2019, CREA joined with several partners to launch the Nairobi Principles on Abortion, Prenatal testing and disability. To increase awareness and ensure accessibility, CREA produced three publications: an easy to read version of the Nairobi Principles and reports on country contexts and the advocacy landscape on abortion, prenatal testing and disability. These were disseminated in various convenings including the Expert Group Meeting held by the Special Rapporteur on the rights of persons with disabilities in August 2019 and the UN Population Fund's Nairobi summit in November 2019. Historically, women with disabilities have been systematically excluded from key decision-making spaces. In order to adress this, CREA has been engaging on disability rights issues at the UN level since 2017. In collaboration with Women Enabled International and International Women's Health Coalition, CREA helped ensure voice and visibility of feminist leaders at the annual UN Conference of Committee on the Rights or Persons with Disabilities in June 2019.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
